titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Margaret A. Dakers papers, 1856-1863
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, September 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Letters from John W. Preston to Dakers. In letters written prior to the Civil War, he discusses life aboard the frigate U.S.S. ST. LAWRENCE; a voyage from Norfolk, Va. to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; and his work as a bookbinder in Washington, D.C. There are five letters written by Preston to his aunt during the Civil War. These letters describe army life, the capture of Winchester, Va., and the march to Martinsburg, Va. (now in W. Va.).

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Margaret A. Dakers Papers, 1856-1863, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, September 2018.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Margaret A. Dakers was a resident of Baltimore, Md., and aunt of John W. Preston, a Civil War soldier of the 1st Md. Infantry Regiment.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letters from John W. Preston to Dakers. In letters written prior to the Civil War, he discusses life aboard the frigate U.S.S. ST. LAWRENCE; a voyage from Norfolk, Va. to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; and his work as a bookbinder in Washington, D.C. There are five letters written by Preston to his aunt during the Civil War. These letters describe army life, the capture of Winchester, Va., and the march to Martinsburg, Va. (now in W. Va.).
